origin_history: Planted in brown raised bed 2' × 6' × 10" in early November 2025.
Originally shared Stake 2 with Zucchini (removed Nov 19, 2025).
Replaced with Miracle-Gro Potting Mix to improve aeration.
whats_been_logged: The plant has progressed from early vegetative expansion into early flowering, with strong branching and healthy foliage following soil aeration and moisture-retention improvements. Recent tracking includes blossom development and maintaining steady root-zone moisture and wind protection to support successful pod set.
current_state: Upright, healthy bush bean with firm green foliage and multiple flowering node clusters producing open white blossoms and tight green buds. Leaves remain evenly green with no visible disease, and older minor chewing damage appears cosmetic and not progressing.

timeline.what_i_should_see: Bushy Shape Forming with Upright Central Stems
Multiple Side Branches at Leaf Nodes
Leaf Canopy Thickening and Filling Space Around Stake
Small Flower Buds at Upper Nodes
Thin Green Bean Pods Behind Spent Flowers
Continuous New Pods Forming After Harvest

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 82°F dropping to 60°F overnight. Tonight: Mostly Clear. Tomorrow: Sunny with a high of 83°F.
journal.observations: Plant appears healthy and vigorous with strong green leaves and upright growth. No visible wilting or leaf curl. Positioned near a zucchini plant that is casting some shade, but leaf size and structure still indicate good active growth. Soil conditions appear stable and evenly moist based on probe readings.
journal.actions: Water in the early morning before heat builds (moderate watering at the base). Continue monitoring for any signs of pale new growth due to low nutrient availability (low EC and fertility).
journal.next_steps: If leaves begin to lighten or growth slows over the next few days, apply a light feeding to support flowering and pod set. Continue consistent morning watering on sunny days, especially as blooms and pods begin forming. Reduce watering only if moisture readings remain consistently above the mid-to-high 50% range.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed whether morning watering was needed given the afternoon moisture reading; recommended a moderate early watering today to prevent midday stress during another hot, sunny day and to maintain steady moisture for flowering and pod development.
follow_up: [8:10 AM] Watered slowly at the base of the plant for 45–75 seconds to keep the root zone evenly moist heading into another hot, sunny day.

photos.caption: Green bean plant growing beside a support stake with healthy green leaves; nearby zucchini foliage is casting partial shade over the area.
photos.tags: green beans, healthy foliage, partial shade, stake support, raised bed

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 83°F dropping to 59°F overnight. Tonight: Increasing clouds. Tomorrow: Decreasing clouds with a high of 69°F.
journal.observations: Green bean plant remains upright and green with active flower clusters forming. Leaves are turgid and not wilted, but probe readings indicate an extremely dry and nutrient-depleted soil pocket in the afternoon heat. Raised bed conditions are drying rapidly despite morning watering, likely due to high soil temperature and uneven moisture distribution. Close inspection shows small soft-bodied insects consistent with aphids or early whitefly activity on leaf surfaces.
journal.actions: Re-wet the root zone lightly this evening with a slow, gentle watering at the base for 30–45 seconds after sun exposure decreases. Apply Bonide Captain Jack’s DeadBug this evening, coating leaf undersides and stems where insects are present. Plan a light fertilizer application tomorrow morning using a diluted liquid feed to restore nutrient availability.
journal.next_steps: Feed tomorrow morning with a light soil drench once moisture is restored to support flowering and pod set. Continue monitoring afternoon moisture levels and expect increased water demand during hot days. Recheck insect pressure 48 hours after treatment and reapply if necessary. Adjust watering duration if probe readings continue to hit zero by mid-afternoon.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Reviewed unexpectedly dry afternoon probe readings despite morning watering and discussed how heat and uneven soil moisture can cause rapid dry pockets. Confirmed that a small supplemental evening watering is appropriate, along with beginning light fertilization due to very low nutrient readings. Identified visible insects as a true pest presence and confirmed that an evening application of Captain Jack’s DeadBug is appropriate.

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 80°F dropping to 58°F overnight. Tonight: Mostly Clear. Tomorrow: Sunny with a high of 82°F.
journal.observations: Green bean plant is upright and vigorous with multiple flower clusters forming. Leaves are mostly healthy green, but at least one lower leaf shows spotting and chewing holes. The plant is receiving heavy shade from a large zucchini leaf during prime sun hours, which may reduce flowering and pod set if it continues. Watering has been occurring consistently in the early mornings, and today’s conditions are sunny and warm with mild overnight cooling.
journal.actions: Remove the spotty/chewed lower leaf now with clean snips and discard it. Lift and secure the shading zucchini leaf away from the bean canopy to restore direct sunlight. Plan a moderate base watering at 6:00 AM tomorrow to keep moisture stable during flowering: gentle shower at the base for 45–75 seconds (or 25–40 seconds if soil is already cool/damp).
journal.next_steps: Monitor upper leaves for any new spotting and watch for increased chewing damage. If shade cannot be reduced daily, expect fewer flowers and possible flower drop. Continue early-morning watering for consistency while flowering and early pod set are underway, adjusting duration based on soil feel. Consider a very light feeding only after pods begin setting if growth slows and fertility remains low.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed zucchini shading during bean flowering and confirmed it should be lifted/secured to improve pod set. Discussed the spotty, chewed lower leaf and confirmed it should be removed to improve airflow and reduce disease risk. Discussed watering timing and confirmed a small, steady morning watering is appropriate since midday watering is not possible.

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 81°F dropping to 58°F overnight.
journal.observations: The Green Bean plant remains upright and healthy with evenly green trifoliate leaves and active flowering at multiple nodes. Leaf posture is firm with no visible wilt or stress, and the root-zone moisture remains in an ideal range despite a dry-looking soil surface. Blossoms and buds are present at the node clusters, indicating continued progression toward early pod set.
journal.actions: Skip watering tomorrow morning, as root-zone moisture remains ideal for flowering and early pod set. Use a quick midday reading or leaf check to confirm the plant stays turgid, and water only if moisture drops below approximately 25 mS/cm. Avoid spraying any products directly onto blossoms.
journal.next_steps: Check readings midday tomorrow if possible and continue allowing gentle dry-down cycles between waterings to maintain oxygen in the root zone. Watch for thin green pods forming behind spent blossoms over the next several days. Continue monitoring pH trends across the next few readings before making any corrections.
journal.q_and_a_summary: User asked whether to water tomorrow morning since readings cannot be taken until midday; advised skipping morning watering because moisture is already ideal and using a midday threshold-based decision (water only if moisture drops below ~25 mS/cm or leaves soften).

photos.caption: Overhead view showing a healthy, upright Green Bean plant with evenly green trifoliate leaves and active flowering nodes around the stake.

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 80°F dropping to 62°F overnight.
journal.observations: The Green Bean plant is upright and vigorous with evenly green trifoliate foliage and multiple node clusters producing open white blossoms and tight buds. Flowering is active across the upper nodes, and leaf posture appears firm with no visible wilt. Soil surface appears dry and lightly crusted, but root-zone moisture remains stable.
journal.actions: Do not water today, as root-zone moisture is in an ideal range for flowering and early pod set. Loosely secure flowering stems and side shoots to the stake to reduce wind movement and prevent blossom drop. Avoid spraying any products directly onto blossoms.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture tomorrow morning and water only if readings fall below approximately 25 mS/cm during flowering. Watch for thin green pods forming directly behind spent blossoms as the next milestone. Continue monitoring for any increase in chewing damage on new growth before considering pest intervention.

photos.caption: Wide view of the Green Bean plant in the raised bed showing upright structure, healthy leaf color, and active growth around the stake.
Overhead view showing multiple active nodes and healthy trifoliate leaves with developing flower clusters.
Close-up of flowering node cluster showing open white bean blossoms and developing buds at the leaf junctions.

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 80°F dropping to 60°F overnight. Wind gusts as high as 28 mph.
journal.observations: The Green Bean plant is upright and healthy with multiple node clusters actively producing white blossoms and tight green flower buds. Leaf structure is firm and evenly green with no visible disease symptoms. Soil appears somewhat dry at the surface, and the plant is entering its flowering phase.
journal.actions: Water slowly at the base today to raise root-zone moisture back into the mid-range, focusing around the dripline rather than directly on the stem. Secure the main stem and flowering side shoots loosely to the stake to protect blossoms from 28 mph wind gusts.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture tomorrow morning or early afternoon and aim to keep readings from dropping below 25 during flowering and early pod set. Watch the flower clusters for spent blossoms followed by thin green pods forming behind them. Monitor for wind damage or blossom drop during gusty afternoons.
journal.q_and_a_summary: User asked what the small white nubs were; confirmed they are bean flower buds and open blossoms, indicating the plant has entered flowering and will soon begin forming pods.

photos.caption: Overhead view showing healthy trifoliate leaves and multiple flowering nodes developing along the main stems.
Close-up of flowering clusters showing open white bean blossoms and tightly formed green buds at the leaf nodes.
Side view showing the main stem supported near the stake with multiple active nodes transitioning into flowering.

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 82°F dropping to 66°F overnight.
journal.observations: The Green Bean plant shows improved vigor with upright posture, open leaves, and active new growth at multiple nodes. Side branching is beginning to develop, and leaf color is evenly green with no signs of wilt or nutrient stress. Overall structure appears more stable following recent watering and improved light exposure.
journal.actions: Do not water today, as soil moisture remains in an ideal range and the plant shows no signs of stress. Maintain current light exposure and avoid additional inputs.
journal.next_steps: Allow the soil to dry down naturally and recheck moisture at the next probe reading. Watch for increased side branching and fuller canopy development over the next several days.
follow_up: [2:30 PM] Noted generalized drooping across the raised bed and applied a light shower to rehydrate foliage and surface soil.

photos.caption: Overhead view showing open leaves and improved canopy structure following light restoration.
Side view highlighting upright stems and early side branching at lower nodes.
Angled view showing active new growth and balanced leaf spacing in full vegetative recovery.

journal.conditions: Patchy fog before 8 AM, otherwise partly sunny with a high near 84°F dropping to around 61°F overnight.
journal.observations: The Green Bean plant shows improved upright structure with active new growth at upper nodes and intact newer leaves. Lower early foliage shows age-related decline and cosmetic chewing damage. Growth remains somewhat leggy, likely influenced by shading from nearby zucchini, while overall leaf color and turgor remain healthy.
journal.actions: Do not water tonight, as overnight conditions will slow evaporation and the plant is not showing wilt. Reduce shading by repositioning or trimming nearby zucchini foliage to restore direct sun exposure. Optionally remove the lowest damaged leaf if desired.
journal.next_steps: Recheck soil moisture tomorrow morning and water only if readings drop below approximately 12 mS/cm or if the plant shows softening. Monitor for increased side branching once light exposure improves. Continue observing new leaves for any pest damage.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed whether the plant is improving and confirmed slight structural improvement. Explained that bush beans do not prefer shade and that zucchini canopy shading can cause leggy growth.
follow_up: [11:00 PM] Applied approximately ½ gallon of water at the base of the Green Bean plant and added Miracle-Gro Moisture Control Potting Mix around the root zone to improve moisture retention.
[11:15 PM] Trimmed back zucchini foliage to remove canopy shade and restore direct light exposure to the Green Bean plant.

photos.caption: Overhead view showing upright structure and active upper growth.
Side view highlighting vertical growth and limited lower branching.
Close-up of lower leaf showing age-related decline and cosmetic chewing damage.
Wide view showing proximity to zucchini and resulting canopy shade before trimming.
Post-trimming view showing restored light access after zucchini canopy was reduced.

journal.conditions: Partly sunny with a high of 83°F dropping to 67°F overnight.
journal.observations: The Green Bean plant remains upright with active new growth at upper nodes and healthy green leaf color. Lower early leaves show cosmetic chewing damage and age-related decline, while newer leaves remain intact and unaffected. Soil is evenly moist following morning rainfall, with no signs of wilting, nutrient stress, or disease.
journal.actions: Do not water today, as soil moisture is already in an ideal range. Do not apply insecticide or neem, as chewing damage is limited to older leaves and is not progressing. Optionally remove the lowest damaged leaf for cosmetic cleanup.
journal.next_steps: Monitor new growth over the next 3–5 days for increased side branching and canopy fill. Recheck moisture once readings fall below approximately 35 mS/cm. Watch for any chewing on new leaves before considering pest intervention.

photos.caption: Overhead view showing active upper growth and healthy leaf color despite sparse early foliage.
Side view highlighting upright stems and upward growth habit around the central stake.
Close-up of lower leaf showing cosmetic chewing damage confined to older foliage.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high near 80°F dropping to around 65°F overnight.
journal.observations: The Green Bean plant remains upright and vigorous with firm stems, expanding trifoliate leaves, and active side branching. Leaf color is uniform and healthy with no wilting or stress symptoms. The soil surface had crusted from wind exposure, causing initial probe insertion difficulty; after fluffing and watering, moisture penetration and root-zone hydration were restored.
journal.actions: Do not water further today. Keep the soil surface lightly fluffed to prevent crusting and allow excess moisture to drain naturally.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture tomorrow to confirm it settles into the mid-range. Monitor for continued canopy thickening and steady side branch growth. Resume normal watering cadence once moisture drops below approximately 35 mS/cm.

photos.caption: Overhead view showing healthy leaf expansion and balanced bush form after rehydration.
Side view highlighting upright stems and symmetrical side branching.
Close-up of new growth showing active trifoliate leaf expansion and healthy texture.

journal.conditions: A 20 percent chance of showers and thunderstorms, partly sunny with a high of 81°F dropping to 63°F overnight.
journal.observations: The Green Bean plant shows excellent recovery with firm, upright stems and fully turgid trifoliate leaves. Multiple side branches are actively developing at the nodes, and new growth tips are elongating. Leaf color is uniform and healthy with no signs of moisture stress or nutrient imbalance. Older lower leaves retain minor cosmetic chewing without progression.
journal.actions: Do not water or fertilize today, as soil moisture and nutrient levels are ideal. Maintain stake stability to protect against wind gusts.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture tomorrow to confirm it remains in the mid-range. Monitor for continued canopy thickening and advancing side branches. Maintain consistent moisture as the plant approaches early flower bud formation.

photos.caption: Overhead view showing healthy leaf expansion and balanced bush structure.
Side view highlighting upright stems and active side branching along the main stem.
Close-up of new growth tips showing active elongation and healthy leaf texture.

journal.conditions: Showers likely with a high of 81°F dropping to 63°F overnight.
journal.observations: The Green Bean plant remains upright with multiple side branches and healthy green trifoliate leaves. New growth is active at the nodes with no wilting or discoloration. Lower leaves show older cosmetic chewing but no progression into new growth. Soil surface and probe readings indicate the root zone is now very dry.
journal.actions: Apply 1½ cups of water slowly around the dripline to rehydrate the root zone. Do not fertilize and do not apply pest treatments today.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture tomorrow and confirm readings rise above 30 mS/cm. Monitor new leaf tips for accelerated expansion following rehydration. Maintain consistent moisture as the plant approaches early flowering.

photos.caption: Overhead view showing compact bush form with multiple branching points and healthy leaf color.
Side view highlighting upright stems and active node development along the main branches.
Close-up of lower foliage showing older cosmetic chewing damage without spread to new leaves.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high of 79°F dropping to 62°F overnight.
journal.observations: The Green Bean plant shows healthy early vegetative growth with upright stems, expanding trifoliate leaves, and active node development. Leaf color is a consistent medium green with no signs of nutrient stress or wilting. Minor chewing damage remains limited to older lower leaves and is not present on new growth. Soil structure around the base appears stable and well-aerated.
journal.actions: Apply 1 cup of water slowly around the dripline to raise soil moisture into the ideal mid-range. Do not fertilize and do not apply any pest treatments at this time.
journal.next_steps: Recheck soil moisture tomorrow to confirm it rises above the low range. Continue monitoring new leaves for any fresh chewing damage. Expect continued vegetative expansion under current temperatures and sun exposure.

photos.caption: Overhead view showing compact bush structure with healthy, expanding trifoliate leaves.
Side view illustrating upright stems and balanced spacing around the base of the plant.
Close-up of the main stem showing active node development and new leaf formation.
Lower foliage displaying older cosmetic chewing damage with no spread to new leaves.

journal.conditions: Mostly Sunny with a high of 73°F dropping to 53°F overnight.
journal.observations: The plant shows stable, healthy early vegetative growth with firm posture and expanding trifoliate leaves. Lower, older leaves display chewing damage consistent with small beetles or caterpillars, but new growth remains clean and unaffected. Soil appears well-aerated and settled after recent correction, and no signs of wilt or stress are present. Current environmental temperatures fall well within the plant’s comfort range.
journal.actions: Apply a light watering of 1 cup around the dripline to support moisture stability overnight. Do not apply any pesticide at this time, as chewing is limited to older leaves and does not affect new growth. Adjust nearby zucchini leaf shading if needed to provide more consistent morning light.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture tomorrow morning to confirm hydration stability. Monitor the newest trifoliate leaves for chewing damage; intervene only if new growth becomes affected. Expect accelerated vegetative expansion over the next several days with ideal temperatures and improved soil conditions.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed whether forecast temperatures pose a risk and confirmed they remain well within safe limits for bush beans.

photos.caption: Overhead view showing the plant’s expanding leaf canopy and overall healthy structure.
Close view of lower leaf displaying chewing damage limited to older foliage.
Detailed look at holes and edge bites on the lower leaf surface.
Side angle showing lower leaves with cosmetic chewing while new growth remains intact.
Another close-up of the lower foliage, highlighting minor chewing without spread to new leaves.

journal.conditions: Slight Chance T-storms then Showers Likely with a high of 83°F dropping to 63°F overnight.
journal.observations: The raised bed soil was initially tight and compacted due to the underlying sand and topsoil mix. After removing the restrictive layer around the bean plant while preserving the root ball, the soil structure became looser and more aerated. The plant remained upright and healthy throughout the process, showing no signs of shock, wilt, or stress. Leaves remain bright and turgid with continued new growth at the nodes. The 'after' reading showed extremely low moisture in the freshly added soil, which was expected since no watering had occurred yet.
journal.actions: Allow the new soil to settle naturally. Provide gentle watering only as needed once rainfall patterns stabilize. Avoid fertilizing today as the refreshed soil provides adequate nutrients for the current growth stage.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture the following morning after rainfall to confirm the new soil layer has hydrated into the proper range. Monitor the plant over the next 1–2 days for continued upright posture and steady leaf expansion. Expect rapid vegetative growth now that soil aeration and structure have improved.
follow_up: [10:00 AM] Gave the plant a light shower to remove soil from the leaves and help the new soil settle.
[5:46 PM] Did not water because it rained today.

photos.caption: Before photo showing compacted topsoil and sand mixture around the bean plant prior to correction.
After photo showing loosened, aerated soil surrounding the base of the bean plant.
Close view of the bean stem and developing nodes following soil correction.

journal.conditions: Slight Chance T-storms then Showers Likely with a high of 83°F dropping to 63°F overnight.
journal.observations: The bean seedling is upright with bright, healthy leaves and active new growth at multiple nodes. Leaf color is consistent and the plant shows early branching typical of Bush Jade beans. The soil is in a low moisture state but still within a safe dry-down range, especially with incoming rain expected later today.
journal.actions: Hold off on watering due to anticipated rainfall later today. Do not fertilize at this stage. Leave all developing nodes and new leaf clusters untouched as they are part of normal vegetative expansion.
journal.next_steps: Check moisture tomorrow after the rain to ensure it rises into the mid-range. Monitor node development as new trifoliate leaves unfold over the next several days. Expect early flower bud formation in the upcoming 10–14 days.
journal.q_and_a_summary: User asked whether the small green clusters on the stem were baby beans; confirmed they are new leaf nodes and early branching points, not bean pods.

photos.caption: Green Bean plant showing bright foliage and upright growth around the central stake.
Overhead perspective highlighting vigorous new leaf development.
Close-up of the stem showing developing nodes forming future leaves and branches.

journal.conditions: Patchy morning fog followed by sun with a high near 86°F and an overnight low around 66°F. Forecast for the following day includes mostly sunny skies near 87°F with a 20% chance of showers after 1 PM.
journal.observations: The Green Bean plant showed vigorous top growth with multiple stems and expanding trifoliate leaves. However, the soil at the probe depth was extremely dry, resulting in zeroed moisture and pH readings despite the plant still appearing relatively turgid. This reflects how quickly the raised bed dries under warm, sunny Florida conditions.
journal.actions: Insert the digital probe near the base at standard depth; soil was too dry for the device to register meaningful values. Provide a focused watering at the base later in the afternoon or early evening, applying enough to moisten the mound and the immediate root zone without flooding the entire bed.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture 60-90 minutes after watering to ensure readings return to the normal range. Given the rapid drying pattern, check soil earlier in the day and plan smaller, more frequent waterings focused at the root zone.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Explained that the all-zero readings are caused by extreme dryness and confirmed that, given the hot, sunny forecast, the plant should be watered even though it still appears outwardly healthy.

photos.caption: Front view of the Green Bean plant showing vigorous leafy growth around the central stake.
Close-up of lower stems and nodes where multiple shoots branch from the base.
Top-down view highlighting the dense canopy and lightly crusted, very dry soil surface.
Wider shot showing the bean plant's position within the raised bed next to neighboring crops.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high of 84°F dropping to 64°F overnight.
journal.observations: At 2 PM the soil was so dry that the digital probe could not register a reading, consistent with the plant's exposure to full Florida sun. After watering, the plant remained upright with leaves fully extended, showing no significant stress or burn. Evening probe readings captured moderately low moisture, reflecting the recent rehydration of an otherwise dry root zone.
journal.actions: Attempt a reading at 2:00 PM but soil was too dry for conductivity. Water the plant thoroughly at the base, then wait over two hours before inserting the probe again and recording the new values.
journal.next_steps: Given the rapid drying pattern, check soil earlier in the day and plan smaller, more frequent waterings focused at the root zone. Avoid saturating beyond the mound to keep oxygen available to the roots.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Clarified how extreme surface dryness can prevent the probe from reading at all and confirmed that watering, then waiting before rechecking, is the right procedure.

photos.caption: Top view of the Green Bean plant after watering, with leaves spread around the central stake.
Side view showing upright stems and well-defined soil mound around the base.
Close-up of lower stems illustrating new side shoots along the main stem.
Evening shot of the plant in relation to the surrounding bed and neighboring crops.

journal.conditions: Mostly Sunny with a high of 82°F dropping to 62°F overnight.
journal.observations: Bean plant maintained vigorous growth under bright mid-day sun with no wilting, and leaf color remained a healthy medium green. Moisture reading remained comfortably in the mid-range, indicating the root zone was still benefiting from prior rainfall and watering without signs of saturation.
journal.actions: Perform a mid-day digital probe reading without additional watering or soil amendments.
journal.next_steps: Continue monitoring daily; plan the next watering when moisture readings begin trending into the low range or when the top 1-2 inches of soil are dry to the touch.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Reinforced that consistent mid-range moisture readings suggest the current watering schedule is appropriate and that over-watering is not needed while the plant looks turgid and healthy.

photos.caption: Probe reading screen showing balanced moisture and pH values for the Green Bean bed.

journal.conditions: Mostly Cloudy with a high of 84°F dropping to 67°F overnight. Wind gusts up to 19 mph.
journal.observations: Plant displayed strong upright growth with several sets of true leaves and light chewing damage but no major defoliation. Soil moisture registered in the mid-range, suggesting the previous rain and watering cycle were still supporting the root zone. Windier conditions caused some leaf movement but stems remained firm.
journal.actions: Take digital probe reading near the base of the plant without additional watering or amendments. Review on-hand garden products for possible future pest and nutrient management.
journal.next_steps: Hold off on watering until the top inch of soil feels dry, given the current moderate moisture value. Use Captain Jack's or neem only if chewing damage significantly increases and always apply in the evening to avoid leaf burn.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Provided an inventory-aware overview of available products (organic fertilizers, dolomite lime, and several insect control options) and discussed that no treatments were immediately required given the mild chewing and overall healthy growth.

photos.caption: Green Bean plant with multiple true leaves and a well-defined soil mound.
Closer view of foliage showing minor chewing along some leaf edges.
Side angle of the plant showing spacing between beans and neighboring crops.
Top-down perspective of the plant highlighting even canopy development.
Probe device nearby ready for use in the Green Bean bed.

journal.conditions: Partly cloudy and mild with temperatures in the upper 70s°F dropping to the mid 60s°F overnight. Earlier rain left the raised bed damp before the reading.
journal.observations: The Green Bean plant continued to gain height with several sets of true leaves and no major pest damage. Despite repeated attempts earlier in the day, the probe would not register until additional organic mix was added to the surface to improve contact. Once readings were obtained, moisture was in a moderate range though the pH reading appeared anomalously high compared to previous days.
journal.actions: Add more organic potting mix around the base and over the mound to improve probe contact where the soil surface had become uneven. No intentional watering done; moisture came from prior rainfall.
journal.next_steps: Recalibrate the digital probe before the next session to verify the high pH reading and continue monitoring moisture without adding more water until the surface begins to dry.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed that difficulty getting readings was likely from poor probe contact rather than sudden soil changes and that unusual pH values should be cross-checked after calibration rather than acted on immediately.

photos.caption: Evening view of the Green Bean plant after additional soil was added around the stem.
Side angle showing the bean plant sharing the bed with nearby zucchini foliage.
Closer shot of foliage showing continued vertical growth and intact leaf surfaces.
Top-down view highlighting the soil mound built up around the main stem.
Probe device positioned near the bed used to check moisture and pH in the newly added soil.

journal.conditions: Mostly Sunny with a high of 77°F dropping to 66°F overnight. Partly cloudy conditions expected around 1 PM with wind gusts up to 15 mph.
journal.observations: Green Bean plant showed steady vegetative growth with multiple true leaves and no signs of wilting or stress. Soil around the base was evenly moist from the morning watering, and the raised mound remained slightly darker and looser than the surrounding bed. Probe insertion produced a stable reading after the hole from the previous day was filled in and leveled.
journal.actions: Give the plant a thorough watering at 9:40 AM focused at the base, then backfill the prior probe hole with soil and lightly level the mound to improve future probe contact.
journal.next_steps: Monitor moisture over the next 24 hours and hold off on additional watering until the top 1-2 inches begin to dry, given the current moderate moisture and mild temperatures.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Confirmed that watering earlier in the day was appropriate and that backfilling probe holes helps maintain consistent readings and root-zone structure.

photos.caption: Green Bean plant in the raised bed after morning watering with soil mound leveled.
Closer view of foliage showing healthy, fully expanded true leaves.
Side angle of the plant showing spacing to the stake and surrounding bed.

journal.conditions: Cloudy with a high of 72°F and low of 57°F. Clear conditions expected around 6 PM.
journal.observations: Plant showing strong upward growth with healthy bright green leaves and a fully emerging new trifoliate. Older minor chew marks unchanged. Soil surface appears dry but lower soil remains moist. False-zero moisture reading due to dry top layer and cool soil temperature.
journal.actions: No watering recommended today due to sufficient moisture beneath the dry surface. No neem needed as no new chewing observed. No soil adjustments required.
journal.next_steps: Tomorrow, if the digital probe still reads zero moisture, perform a probe watering correction: add 1 cup of water directly at the probe site, wait 20-30 minutes, recheck moisture.

photos.caption: Morning reading showing seedling upright with bright green foliage.
Top view showing new trifoliate leaf emerging clean and healthy.
Side view showing overall structural progress and stable soil mound.

journal.conditions: Cloudy with a high of 81°F and low of 65°F. Rain expected around 6 PM.
journal.observations: Plant upright with vigorous leaf expansion and active new growth. Light chewing observed but unchanged from prior day. Soil evenly moist throughout core layer.
journal.actions: No watering due to adequate moisture and incoming rain. Neem still not recommended due to plant age and limited chewing.
journal.next_steps: Monitor chewing daily but wait for the plant to establish more true leaves before applying neem.

photos.caption: Overhead shot showing healthy new leaf development.
Side view with stable upright posture.
Soil profile showing good moisture retention.

journal.conditions: Mostly cloudy with a high of 84°F and low of 67°F. Thunderstorms expected around 4 PM.
journal.observations: Rapid growth with new leaves unfolding. Slight chewing on lower leaves but no worsening. Soil moisture stable and appropriate.
journal.actions: No watering due to approaching storms. No neem application recommended yet.
journal.next_steps: Check for chewing again after storms in case pests hide under moist conditions.

photos.caption: Overhead view showing expanding leaf set.
Angle showing strong stem structure.
Probe placement verifying accurate reading zone.

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 84°F and low of 65°F. Watered at 2:33 PM; readings taken 1.5 hours later.
journal.observations: Strong new growth and healthy color. Soil still wet from watering, producing elevated moisture and fertility readings.
journal.actions: No additional watering required. No pest treatment necessary.
journal.next_steps: Allow soil to dry back to normal range before next watering.

photos.caption: Bean seedling with healthy leaf spread.
Top-down view showing leaf arrangement.
Close shot of true-leaf development.
Soil mound post-watering.

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 84°F and low of 60°F.
journal.observations: Healthy seedling with bright leaves, clean stem, and stable soil mound. Early true leaves expanding well. Probe placed carefully due to seedling fragility.
journal.actions: No watering required at the time of reading. No pest actions.
journal.next_steps: Continue monitoring moisture daily as soil settles.

photos.caption: Probe placement check confirming safe distance from stem.
Healthy seedling with strong early growth.

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 84°F and overnight low around 63°F. Soil below and within the new organic mound was extremely dry at the time of the initial measurement.
journal.observations: Initial probe returned all-zero readings due to extreme dryness in both the organic mound and underlying sand-heavy soil, preventing proper electrical conductivity. Despite this, the Green Bean seedling remained upright and healthy with expanding true leaves. Spider webs present between the fence and stake were identified as beneficial predators and not harmful to plant growth.
journal.actions: Apply a targeted shower of water directly to the base and the organic mound, carefully avoiding the leaves, to rehydrate the soil profile enough for proper probe readings.
journal.next_steps: Allow 45-60 minutes for moisture to wick through the soil layers before taking a follow-up reading. Monitor the bed as it transitions away from the sand-dominant dryness and recalibrate the probe for accurate pH measurement.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Explained that all-zero readings were caused by extreme soil dryness preventing electrical contact. Confirmed spider webs were safe and beneficial natural pest control.
follow_up: [4:04 PM] Follow-up reading after watering: pH 10.23, EC 0.05 mS/cm, Salt 27 mg/L, Moisture 26.00 mS/cm, Light 99, RH 40%, Fertility 2.5%, Soil Temp 82.6°F.

photos.caption: Green Bean seedling with dry soil before watering.
Post-watering view showing seedling and surrounding soil.
Close-up of the seedling showing true leaf development.
Spider webs visible between fence and stake near the seedling.
Follow-up probe placement beside the seedling at 4:04 PM.

journal.conditions: Mostly cloudy with a high of 84°F and overnight low around 67°F. Soil was amended with organic potting mix earlier today to improve moisture retention.
journal.observations: Green Bean seedling remains upright with developing true leaves and a healthy mid-green color. The newly added organic potting mix has improved soil texture and moisture retention, correcting the previous dryness from the sand-heavy substrate. The temporary pH spike is attributed to the recent amendment and watering and does not reflect true soil conditions. Leaves show smooth texture and no signs of pests or stress.
journal.actions: Add a mound of organic potting mix to increase moisture retention and soil quality, followed by a small amount of water to settle the new soil.
journal.next_steps: Allow soil to equilibrate over the next 24-48 hours before rechecking pH. Monitor moisture and avoid additional watering until the top layer begins to dry. Begin fertilizer only when true leaves fully expand.
journal.q_and_a_summary: User asked whether the soil adjustment and subsequent readings were expected. Confirmed that pH spikes and moisture changes are normal following amendments and will stabilize soon.

photos.caption: Green Bean seedling after soil amendment with organic potting mix.
Close-up showing leaf color and true leaf development.
Freshly added organic potting mix around the seedling for moisture retention.
Seedling posture and new soil mound viewed from the side.

journal.conditions: Sunny afternoon with a high of 84°F and expected overnight low around 60°F.
journal.observations: The Green Beans seedling is upright and stable with cotyledons open and early true leaves developing. Color appears healthy with no signs of scorch, pests, or disease. Soil surface is visibly dry, consistent with the probe reading of 0.00 moisture. Removal of the nearby zucchini has opened space around the root zone, improving airflow, light access, and reducing competition.
journal.actions: Apply 1/4-1/3 cup of water in a ring around the plant to rehydrate the root zone. No fertilizer added as true leaves are still forming.
journal.next_steps: Monitor moisture over the next 24 hours and continue gentle watering as the top layer dries. Begin considering first light fertilizer only when the first true leaves are fully open and sized up.
journal.q_and_a_summary: User noted that the zucchini is now removed and the beans now have their own space. Confirmed this benefits root-zone access, airflow, light, and growth rate.

photos.caption: Green Bean seedling upright with developing true leaves near the stake.
Close-up showing leaf color and soil dryness around the seedling.
Additional angle showing full seedling posture and cleared root zone after zucchini removal.

journal.conditions: Partly shaded morning turning sunny later with temperatures in the upper 60s°F and calm weather.
journal.observations: Two Bush Jade bean seedlings upright and stable near the stake with early cotyledon opening. Color consistent with healthy new sprouts, no scorch or pest damage. Soil moderately moist and recently amended. Probe placement was careful and away from fragile stems while still capturing the root-zone conditions.
journal.actions: No watering required. Zucchini (Left) that shared the root zone was removed by cutting at the soil line to prevent root disturbance and free the stake space for the beans.
journal.next_steps: Monitor for upright posture and continued leaf expansion. Recheck moisture before the next watering. Consider first fertilizer only after true leaves are established.
journal.q_and_a_summary: User asked if removing the zucchini was appropriate and whether cutting instead of pulling was safer. Confirmed cutting was the correct approach to protect bean roots.
follow_up: [3:30 PM] Zucchini (Left) was removed by cutting at the soil line so the Green Beans could fully occupy the stake and root zone with minimal root disturbance.

photos.caption: Green Beans seedlings near the stake with careful probe placement.
Close-up of cotyledons and soil structure on 11/19.
Stake area after Zucchini (Left) was removed.

journal.conditions: Mostly shady morning with temperatures in the mid-60s°F, transitioning to full sun by late morning.
journal.observations: Two bean sprouts upright and moist from overnight dew. The first sprout had just shed its seed coat. Cotyledons beginning to open with normal pale-green color. Soil moderately moist with loose structure. No signs of pest damage or stress.
journal.actions: No watering required. No fertilizer or neem needed. Allow seedlings to transition into full sun as conditions improve.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture within 24 hours. Begin fertilizer only after true leaves appear. Protect from temperatures below 49°F.
journal.q_and_a_summary: User asked if probe placement was safe and whether seed coat removal was normal. Confirmed both were appropriate.
follow_up: [4:02 PM] Added organic potting mix around the shared area for stability and moisture retention, then applied approximately 1/2 cup water to settle soil.

photos.caption: Digital probe reading for Green Beans on 11/18.
Green Bean sprouts beside Zucchini before removal.
Soil addition during 4:02 PM follow-up.

journal.conditions: Full morning sun with temperatures in the mid-60s°F and light air movement.
journal.observations: Two bean sprouts observed near the stake. One sprout was partially emerged with the seed coat still attached. Soil was dry and loose. No signs of rot or disease.
journal.actions: Apply light watering along with the nearby zucchini area. Mist the stuck seed coat to encourage natural release.
journal.next_steps: Monitor seed coat for loosening. Recheck soil moisture. Avoid fertilizer until true leaves appear.
journal.q_and_a_summary: User asked if the seed coat would fall off naturally and whether misting was appropriate. Confirmed both.

photos.caption: Early bean sprouts near stake on 11/17.

journal.conditions: Clear morning sun with temperatures around 66°F.
journal.observations: First bean sprout observed emerging to the right of the stake. Cotyledons still partially enclosed by seed coat. Soil slightly dry at surface but acceptable. Second sprout not yet visible.
journal.actions: Avoid watering to prevent moisture stress. Light mist approved for softening the stuck seed coat.
journal.next_steps: Monitor sprout over next 12-24 hours for cotyledon opening. Expect second sprout to emerge soon.
journal.q_and_a_summary: User asked whether the seed coat would come off on its own. Confirmed it would naturally loosen and fall.

photos.caption: First emergence of Green Bean sprout on 11/16.
